attributes.alt: Book cover for Creature Features by Penelope Arlon and Tory Gordon-Harris. The cover shows a panda's face, a frog, and a puffer fish.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book
What features do some animals in this book have?
Read for enjoyment and sort animals by attributes.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, in a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to five) scattered.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Challenge children to sort manipulatives by attribute.
Discuss features of each animal and ask children to sort the Activity Cards according to animal features.
What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?
What book did you choose? Why did you choose that one?
Can you pretend to be an animal? What animal are you?
How many are in that group? How do you know?
Can you write about an animal? What are some things you know about that animal?
What shapes do you see? How many shapes are on your page?
What letter did you make? How did you make it?
What are you building? How many blocks have you used so far?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder and review counting.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, in a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to five) scattered.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Use digital learning applications and programs.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Encourage children to ask “why” questions about animals on cards.
Look up answers to children’s questions.
Determine new ways to sort based on newly learned information.
What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?
What are you curious about in that book?
What animal can you pretend to be? Why did you decide to act like that animal?
Why is it helpful to use your hands to count to 10?
Can you write about an animal feature that you are curious about?
Why did you choose the colors you did?
Can you find something in the room that starts with the same sound as /y/ or /z/?
Why did you use those materials to build that animal?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to sort by attribute, count out from 10, and introduce vocabulary
How do the animals in this book use their features?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to sort features into same and different.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, in a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to five) scattered.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 objects into two equal sets or up to five objects into two sets of any amount.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Classify and organize; Categorize items and group or arrange ones that are alike.
Ask children to practice counting out a specific number of “ducks” from a group of 10 “ducks.”
Guide children to classify groups of “ducks” as same or different based on the number in each group.
What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?
Which animal features can you find in that book?
How could you pretend to be a spider?
What two numbers can you add together to make 10 Connecting Cubes in all?
Can you write about an animal with amazing features?
Can you draw two animals that look different?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of your favorite animal name?
What materials could we add to this animal to show its features?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to get children excited to read about animal feet by conducting a foot count, playing a pattern activity, and introducing new vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to operations by separating animal feet into equal groups.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, in a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to five) scattered.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 objects into two equal sets or up to five objects into two sets of any amount.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.
Guide children to separate Connecting Cubes into equal groups of “frogs.”
Have children count the number of cubes in each group and compare.
What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?
What do you think about that book?
Why did you decide to act like that animal instead of a different animal?
How can you separate these into equal groups?
What will you write first and why?
Why did you choose those colors?
Can you look around the room and find more examples of that letter? How many did you count?
How can you make your creation even stronger so it won’t fall?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to connect the book to scientific thinking and to extend the animal pattern activity.
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question,
What are some animal features that you also have?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on operations.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, in a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to five) scattered.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 objects into two equal sets or up to five objects into two sets of any amount.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more; Make connections between situations.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Verbally share the meaning of own writing.
Support children as they independently respond to the prompt: “
What are some animal features that you also have?”
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?
What kind of book would you like to read next?
Pretend to be an animal no one has ever seen. How will you act?
I see 4 mice. How can I put these mice into two equal groups?
What story can you tell about your made-up animal?
Can you draw a kind of animal that no one has ever seen before?
Make up a name for your pretend animal. What sound do you hear at the beginning of the name?
What ideas do you have for building an animal or an animal home? What will you use?
